Class DisjointSets

java.lang.Object
  DisjointSets

public class DisjointSets
extends java.lang.Object

Provides an implementation of weighted union-by-size with full path compression. Most of this code is from Chap. 24 of Data Structures and Problem Solving Using Java 3/E by Mark Allen Weiss. The data structure operation is also explained in Chap. 1 of Algorithms in Java 3/E by Sedgewick.

The structure is initialized with a size representing the number of singleton sets. The elements are assumed to have indices 0 to size-1. The two main operations are union and find. Union joins the sets containing two elements; Find returns the representative element of the set containing a specific element.

If two elements x and y belong to the same set, their find operations should return the same value. Example: 

      DisjointSets d = DisjointSets(5);
              // creates a new structure with 5 singleton sets,
              // {0}, {1}, {2}, {3}, {4}
      
      d.union(1, 3);
      d.union(3, 4);
              // now the structure represents 3 sets,
              // {0}, {1, 3, 4}, {2}
              
      int x = d.find(1);
      int y = d.find(2);
      int z = d.find(3);
              // x == z, but x != y
              
      int c = d.count();
      int s = d.size();
              // c == 3   (number of sets)
              // s == 5   (size of structure)

COSC 102, Colgate University
Part of source code for the maze lab

Constructor Detail

DisjointSets

public DisjointSets(int n)
Initializes a new DisjointSets object with n initial singleton sets.

Parameters:
n - number of initial singleton sets
Method Detail

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Returns the internal representation of the union-find data structure.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
a String containing the values of the array used to hold set pointers and sizes

Dump

public void Dump()
Prints debugging information to stdout. For each element of the array, its index and value are printed on a separate line.

find

public int find(int x)
Implements find with full path compression. Returns an integer representing the set containing x. If i and j are in the same set, then find(i)==find(j).

Parameters:
x - the item whose container set to find
Returns:
a representative element for the set containing x
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if x < 0 or x >= size()

union

public int union(int x,
                 int y)
Implements weighted union by size. Joins the sets containing x and y, such that subsequent find operations on any elements in the sets containing x and y will return the same value.

Parameters:
x - item whose set should be joined
y - item whose set should be joined
Returns:
the size of the unioned set, or -1 if x and y are already in the same set

size

public int size()
Returns the size of the data structure (provided at the time of construction). Unlike count(), the size of the structure does not change once created.

Returns:
the number of original singleton sets

count

public int count()
Returns the number of disjoint sets currently in the data structure. Each successful union operation reduces the number of disjoint sets by one.

Returns:
the number of disjoint sets
